d:chapter.d:title: Introduction
d:chapter.d:para: I do not think I need to introduce GNU/Linux to anyone remotely interested in computers and programming in particular. Well, exceptions are always there like old people who do nothing but browse, chat and email or possibly go to Facebook or kids who have just started working on computers. Some people might have heard the term Ubunut or Fedora or OpenSUSE or Mint or Debian etc and maybe also using them without knowing that essentially all are GNU/Linux variations. You would ask me what is GNU/Linux then because all other names mentioned previously are open source operating system. You might even ask I have heard of Linux what is this GNU? Well, GNU is an acronym which stands for "GNU is not Unix". GNU is an ecosystem which provides Linux as its kernel. And no GNU/Linux is not only an operating system but it is a complete package. For almost all needs you just need to install one of the distributions mentioned. GNU or free software movement was started by Richard Stallman in 1983. The objective was to provide free operating system. What did you say free means no price? No no it means freedom. Free as in freedom not free beer. Remember it and never forget because if you forget or do not respect your freedom you will end up loosing it. GNU was meant to provide freedom both to the programmers and to the users from proprietary software. You do not have to spend zillions of dollars to aquire the software and more importantly you can modify it because source code is available to you. Now note that you can modify it not like other proprietary system where you know there is a problem and you know what is the fix but you cannot apply it even though you have bought it. Consider you have bought a car and it is not working and you know you can fix it then wont you? Will the car company come and stop you? No, right. But in software world in the name of intellectual property rights money is looted from its users for second grade worthless software. You know what I am pointing towards. Oh how I hate you would say. Yes I hate and I pity them together. Is it only their knowledge they are building the software upon. NO! Knowledge has accumulated by the contribution of many people over thousands of years. We learn something from previous generations and we build upon it. Then on what grounds there can be a copyright on knowledge. It is with the same thought I write free books in the free spirit. I would rather live one day as free man and die than live hundred years of luxurious life of slavery. These companies which manufacture proprietary software are trying to enslave the very life.

The first step which you can take is install a distribution of GNU/Linux. I prefer Mint because it ships with Mate as default and its green theme is soothing. It is just a personal perference. Ubuntu is not bad either though they have taken a bad approach towards secure boot. Debian and Cent OS are pretty solid for servers. If you are on one of the popular proprietary systems and afraid of doing a native install then I encourage you to watch my video on how to install Mint GNU/Linux on VirtualBox. You can view this here. I will try to make more such videos and upload them. Now go ahead and take your first step towards freedom by installing one of the distributions of GNU/Linux.

Now that you have installed GNU/Linux I will tell you how to use it. We will start with command line and later we will see at GUI. GUI is easy becasue you can do a lot by yourself. If you have installed Mint with Mate then you have a terminal or in Ubintu you have a terminal. Note that underlyrng terminal is almost same but the difference is in their names. One is called mate-terminal and another is called gnome-terminal. If you have installed KDE based desktop manager then you would have a program called konsole. Just navigat the GUI menus to find them and start them. The menu should be at bottom-left or top-left. Once you are there you would see a prompt ending with $. This sgnifies you are using a bash(bourne again shell) as a normal user. If you are a root (the alll powerful administrator of a Unix or GNU/Linux system) then it would be #. Note that you can not login as root in most of these system but you can do that easily. I will tell you about that later. So now we have this prompt (it is called a prompt because it is asking you to enter a command which it is ready to serve for you if possible and you do not mess that). Let us see what we can do with this prompt.

d:sect1.d:title: Starting with Command Prompt
d:sect1.d:para: Whatever command you enter is first word or string if it has spaces or some special characters. Note that if you have such special stuff then it has to be quoted. For now let us not worry about that and try to see what we have. Most of the commands will be one word or path to one file which must be executable. When I say executable then it means it should be able to execute not only in the sense of permissions. You can mark even a text file executable but that does not mean it will execute meanigfully.
